div1.p: Griffitts discusses vegetation and mosquito larvae in 14 different ponds in the Cherokee Basin.

div1.head: Memorandum from T.H.D. Griffitts to G.H. Hazlehurst, 1924
div1.p:
Memo to Chief Sanitary Engineer, G. H. Hazlehurst
relative to inspection of Gambusia development ponds, Cherokee
Basin, August 21-22, 1924, by Epidemiologist T. H. D. Griffitts.

Pond No. 13 - Liberally supplied with gambusia, all
sizes. Pond covered with black scum, no flotage and little
vegetation. Water running freely around dam; dam in good con-
dition. Out of 32 dips, collected 5 Anopheles larvae, none above
three-fourths grown.

Pond No. 14 - Water low, banks bare. In masses of
moss Anopheles taken every 3 or 4 dips, only one full grown
larva found here. Liberally supplied with Gambusia. Twenty-
nine Anopheles larvae taken in 23 dips.

Pond No. 1 - Liberally supplied with Gambusia. Much
fallen bullrush and algae, breeding now producing Anopheles
quite freely. All sizes of larvae. Twenty full grown larvae
and 8 pupae collected. The development from larvae and pupae
taken from Pond No. 1 was as follows: Four Anopheles quadri-
maculatus.

Pond No. 2 - Located about 40-feet above Pond No. 1.
Almost completely covered with small aquatic vegetation algae
and potomogeton. Many larvae or uranotaenia and only 4 small
Anopheles larvae were collected. Many gambusia noted but not
as many observed as in Pond No. 1.

Pond No. 3 - Liberally stocked with gambusia. Upper
portion overgrown with grass and considerable amount of pine
tag flotage. Twelve full grown Anopheles larvae taken in 40
dips. Pond in good condition. One A. Quadrimaculatus develop-
ed from collection made here.

Pond No. 5 - Liberally supplied with gambusia - only
light Anopheles breeding (1 full grown larva and 1 pupa collected)
Water hot and almost completely covered with scum.

Pond No. 18 - Until recently this pond has been dry.
It was completely filled at the time of inspection. No gambusia
seen and no Anopheles breeding.

Pond No. 24 - Water low; no flotage, contains willows
and burr grass. Gambusia plentiful. Only two small Anopheles
larvae found.

Pond No. 4 - Near Jerry Dennis' house; 14 large
Anopheles larvae and 3 pupae collected in 30 minutes. Found
generally in pine tags and vegetation. Fairly well stocked
with gambusia. No Anopheles found in barn of Jerry Dennis.
Development from collection at Pond No. 4 was as follows:
Seven Quadrimaculatus; two punctipennis.

Pond No. 25 - Pond has overflowed recently. Water
muddy, practically no flotage and no vegetation. Stream enter-
ing pond breeding Anopheles freely - probably Punctipennis.
Very few minnows in this pond.

Pond No. 6 - Six first molt Anopheles larvae collected;
very few gambusia.

Pond No. 8 - Much small bullrush and overfallen vege-
tation covering a good portion of the pond, breeding profusely
and from the number of large larvae and pupae apparently consider-
able production is taking place. Liberally supplied with gambusia.
Gulledge sawmill 200 yards distance where 150 people will be camped
shortly. The development from collection made was as follows:
Seventeen Quadrimaculatus.

This pond is producing Anopheles Quadrimaculatus in
sufficient numbers to be of decided importance in the transmission
of malaria if there should be carriers in the vicinity, and this
is not improbable in a sawmill gang. This pond should be thorough-
ly oiled once every ten days during the remainder of the season.
It is an excellent Gambusia developing pond, therefore, oiling is
recommended in preference to draining it.

Pond No. 10 - Liberally stocked with gambusia. Collect-
ed 10 full grown larvae and 3 pupae in 13 minutes amongst over-
fallen bullrush, grasses, etc. Development from collection was as
follows: Two Quadrimaculatus, 3 Crucians. There is a sawmill
located 1/4 mile from this pond. It is said that no people are
housed at the sawmill. There is no other occupied house near the
pond.

Pond No. 11 - Fairly well stocked with Gambusia. No
aquatic vegetation or flotage. Only small larvae collected here.

Ponds Nos. 1, 4, 8, and 10 are producing Quadrimaculatus
freely and to avoid danger of malaria transmission from mosquito
development in these ponds, it is advisable that they be oiled
thoroughly once every 10 days during mosquito season.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, T. H. D. Griffitts,
Epidemiologist.
